Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Glycera nicobarica?
Expected_answer: Glycera nicobarica Grube, 1866 Body rings are described as bi-annulated in mid-body segments. The prostomium is elongated and conical, longer than wide, with 10-11 rings. The proboscidal papillae exist in two types: 1) conical papillae with three transverse ridges, which are most abundant, and 2) oval-shaped papillae without ridges. The aileron is noted as 'Aileron with a.' The parapodia are such that the first two are uniramous, while subsequent ones are biramous. The prechaetal lobes are triangular with a broad base in the anterior and mid-body, and become digitiform in the posterior segments. The postchaetal lobes are short. Notopodial lobes are triangular, while neuropodial lobes are rounded. The dorsal cirrus begins from the 2nd segment, conical to oval, situated near the parapodial base. Retractile digitiform branchiae are present from segments 19-26 to the posterior end, predominantly visible in mid-body. The chaetae include simple capillaries in notopodia and compound spinigers in neuropodia. The ventral cirrus is broad and triangular in the anterior and mid-body, transforming into a digitiform shape in the posterior. The type locality is the Nicobar Islands, and the species is distributed in the Andaman and Nicobar Islands.
Generated_answer: Glycera nicobarica is characterized by conical proboscidial papillae with three transverse ridges, ailerons with triangular bases, four prostomial antennae, an elongated conical prostomium with 10–11 rings, postchaetal lobes that are short and notopodia triangular, neuropodial lobes rounded, and branchiae absent. The first two setigers are uniramous, followed by biramous parapodia, and mid-body segments are bi-annulated. The proboscis has four curved chitinous jaws followed by soft papillae of two types: most are conical with three ridges, others are oval without ridges. Dorsal cirri start from the 2nd segment, conical to oval, close to the parapodial base. Support: These features are detailed in the diagnosis and description of G. nicobarica, distinguishing it from related taxa.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Glycera oxycephala?
Expected_answer: Glycera oxycephala Ehlers, 1887 features a body with rings that vary along its length: anterior segments are bi-annulated, while mid-body segments are mostly tri-annulated. The elongated, conical prostomium, which is longer than wide, consists of 20-25 indistinct rings. The proboscidal papillae include two types: 1) abundant conical papillae with transverse ridges (11-18), and 2) oval-shaped papillae with transverse ridges (5-9). The aileron has a slightly arched base. Parapodia start as uniramous in the first two segments and become biramous afterward. The prechaetal lobes of notopodia and neuropodia are similar in length and transition from broad bases to digitiform shapes from anterior to posterior segments. The postchaetal lobes are short and rounded throughout. Dorsal cirri are conical to oval, beginning from the 3rd segment, located near the parapodial bases. Branchiae are absent. The chaetae consist of simple capillaries in notopodia and compound spinigers in neuropodia. Ventral cirri are broadly triangular in the front and middle, changing to digitiform toward the rear. The species was first found in Barbados and is distributed across the Atlantic, North Sea, Red Sea, Australia, Madagascar, East Pacific, and India’s Andaman and Nicobar Islands.
Generated_answer: Glycera oxycephala is characterized by a body at least 33 mm long with at least 100 segments, mid-body segments biannulate, a conical prostomium with about 11–13 rings, and a proboscis with three types of papillae. The ailerons have a pointed triangular base. The first two parapodia are uniramous, the rest biramous, with two slender triangular to digitiform prechaetal lobes and two shorter postchaetal lobes. Dorsal cirri start from the 3rd parapodium, and branchiae are absent. Support: Detailed morphological description and diagnostic features are provided for G. oxycephala, including parapodial and proboscidial structures.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Glycera papillosa?
Expected_answer: Glycera papillosa Grube, 1857, has body rings with mid-body segments that are bi-annulated. The prostomium is conical with 8 rings. The proboscidal papillae consist of two types: a few ovoid forms and many long, slender forms without rings. The aileron is deeply forked and slender, with the shorter limb being half the length of the longer one and attached to it. The parapodia initially are uniramous, followed by biramous parapodia. The superior prechaetal lobe is small, while the inferior is large and pointed. A single, rounded postchaetal lobe is present. The small dorsal cirrus arises from the body wall above the parapodium. No branchiae are present or located. The chaetae include simple capillaries in notopodia and compound spinigers in neuropodia. The ventral cirrus has a length comparable to the postchaetal lobe. The type locality is in the Chilean part of the South Pacific Ocean. Its distribution spans the Western Atlantic from North Carolina to the Gulf of Mexico, Chile, Western Africa, and the Indian Ocean including the South Arabian Sea and the Andaman and Nicobar Islands.
Generated_answer: Glycera papillosa is a small species (20–30 mm long) with a prostomium of about eight rings. The proboscis has a few ovoid papillae and numerous very long, slender, non-ringed papillae. Jaw supports are deeply forked and slender. There are no gills. The superior presetal lobe is minute, the inferior one large and pointed, and there is a single broadly rounded postsetal lobe. The dorsal cirrus is small and arises well above the foot. Support: These features distinguish G. papillosa, but its taxonomic status is considered doubtful and possibly synonymous with G. capitata or G. lapidum.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Glycera posterobranchia?
Expected_answer: Glycera posterobranchia Hoagland, 1920 is characterized by body rings, with mid-body segments being bi-annulated. The prostomium is an elongated, conical structure longer than wide, comprising 10-11 rings. The proboscidal papillae include three types: 1) the most common are papillae with terminal fingernail-like tips and a medium stalk with longitudinal ridges; 2) shorter, conical papillae with longitudinal ridges; 3) oval-shaped papillae without ridges. The aileron features a pointed triangular base. Parapodia start as uniramous in the first two segments, then become biramous. The prechaetal lobes are triangular with broad bases in the anterior and mid-body, and digitiform in posterior segments. The postchaetal lobes are short; notopodial lobes are triangular, while neuropodial lobes are rounded. The dorsal cirrus begins from the third segment, shaped conically to oval, situated near the parapodial base. The branchiae are non-retractile, located between the 16th and 24th segments, dorsomedially on the parapodia towards the posterior. The chaetae consist of simple capillaries in notopodia and compound spinigers in neuropodia. The ventral cirrus is broad and triangular in the front and middle parts, changing to a digitiform shape at the rear. The type locality is the Philippines EEZ, with distribution including Philippine Islands, South China Sea, Vietnam, and the Indian Ocean, especially the Bay of Bengal and Andaman and Nicobar Islands.
Generated_answer: Glycera posterobranchia is characterized by a body with at least 124 segments, mid-body segments biannulate, a conical prostomium with about 10 rings, proboscis with three types of papillae (including those with terminal fingernail structure and medium-length stalk), ailerons with pointed triangular bases, first two parapodia uniramous and the rest biramous, mid-body parapodia with two slender triangular to digitiform prechaetal lobes, two shorter postchaetal lobes (notopodial lobe longer and slender triangular, neuropodial lobe rounded or slender triangular in posterior), and dorsal cirri from the 3rd parapodium, conical to oval, inserted on the body wall. Branchiae are simple, digitiform, situated medio-dorsally on parapodia. Support: These features are detailed in the species description and identification keys, highlighting the unique combination of proboscidial papillae, aileron shape, and parapodial lobe structure.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Glycera subaenea?
Expected_answer: Glycera subaenea Grube, 1878 is characterized by body rings where anterior segments are bi-annulated, and mid-body segments are generally tri-annulated. The prostomium is conical, featuring 8-10 rings. The proboscidal papillae include two types: numerous bluntly conical papillae with 1-2 rings and subspherical papillae without rings. The aileron comprises one well-developed prong and another short prong, which is fully united with the first by an oblique shelf. The parapodia start as uniramous in the first two segments and become biramous thereafter. The prechaetal lobes are long, equally pointed, and there are two of them. The postchaetal lobes include a pointed superior lob and a shorter, blunt inferior lob. Branchiae are present, originating from chaetiger 12, positioned on the anterior end of the parapodium, with 2 to 5 branched digitiform lobes. The chaetae consist of simple capillaries in notopodia and compound spinigers in neuropodia. The type locality is recorded as the Philippines EEZ. The species is distributed across the Philippines, Australia, South China Sea, Madagascar, Red Sea, South Africa, and in the Indian Ocean including South Arabian Sea and Andaman and Nicobar Islands.
Generated_answer: Glycera subaenea is considered a synonym of Glycera macintoshi. The type specimen has only a few simple, retractile, digitiform branchiae present on the parapodia, which may be ramified. The genus Glycera is characterized by biramous parapodia (except a few anterior chaetigers), a long, muscular eversible proboscis with numerous papillae, four dark jaws with ailerons, and a pointed, annulated prostomium with four appendages and a pair of nuchal organs. Eyes are absent. Diagnostic features for Glycera species include the type of proboscidial papillae, aileron shape, and the presence/position of branchiae on parapodia. Support: Glycera subaenea is synonymized with G. macintoshi, which has simple, retractile, digitiform branchiae; genus-level traits include biramous parapodia, eversible proboscis with papillae, and four jaws with ailerons.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Glycera sphyrabrancha?
Expected_answer: Glycera sphyrabrancha Schmarda, 1861 is characterized by body rings that are biannulate from chaetiger 10 onward, with the anterior rings being uniannulate. The prostomium is conical, featuring 10-12 rings. Proboscidal papillae are of two types: numerous digitiform papillae without ridges and several isolated, oval to globular papillae also without ridges. The aileron has a deeply incised base. Parapodia first appear uniramous, then become biramous in subsequent segments. The prechaetal lobes are two slender, triangular to digitiform structures on anterior parapodia; noto- and neuropodial prechaetal lobes are generally equal, with middle and posterior parapodia showing slightly longer neuropodial lobes. The postchaetal lobe is rounded. The dorsal cirrus is digitiform, slightly swollen dorsally at the base, longer on anterior and parapodial segments, decreasing in size towards the posterior. The ventral cirrus varies from triangular on anterior segments, digitiform in the middle, to slender on posterior segments. Branchiae are non-retractile, simple, slightly triangular anteriorly, becoming digitiform from the middle of the anterior region, most prominent in the middle body. They appear starting from chaetiger 15 near the upper chaetal lobe. The chaetae include simple capillaries in notopodia and compound spinigers in neuropodia. The type locality is the Jamaican EEZ, and the species distribution includes the Arabian Gulf, Andaman Sea, Aruba, Belize, Caribbean Sea, Cuba, Curaçao, Honduras, Jamaica, Panama, Philippines, Red Sea, South Africa, South China Sea, Tobago, Trinidad, Venezuela, and regions in India such as Andhra Pradesh, Gujarat, Goa, Kerala, Lakshadweep Islands, Maharashtra, Odisha, and West Bengal.
Generated_answer: Glycera sphyrabrancha is characterized by a body with at least 124 segments, mid-body segments biannulate, a conical prostomium with about 10 rings, and a proboscis bearing three types of papillae (including digitiform papillae without ridges). The ailerons have deeply incised bases, and simple digitiform branchiae are present from about parapodium 17–23 to near the posterior end, situated termino-dorsally on parapodia. Parapodia are biramous except for the first two, with two slender triangular to digitiform prechaetal lobes of similar length, and shorter postchaetal lobes. Dorsal cirri start from the 3rd parapodium, conical to oval in shape. Support: These features distinguish G. sphyrabrancha, especially the combination of digitiform, ridge-less proboscidial papillae, deeply incised ailerons, and the presence of simple digitiform branchiae.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Glycera tesselata?
Expected_answer: Glycera tesselata Grube, 1863 is characterized by body rings that are bi-annulated in the anterior segments and more or less tri-annulated in the mid-body segments. The prostomium is conical with 8-9 rings. The proboscidal papillae include two types: mostly digitiform-shaped papillae, with the aileron featuring a deeply incised base. The parapodia initially uniramious, become biramous in the following segments. The prechaetal lobe, triangular with an broad anterior base in the front and mid-body, short and rounded in the posterior segments. The postchaetal lobe remains short and rounded across all segments. The dorsal cirrus, conical to oval, appears from the 3rd segment onward, positioned far from the parapodial basis. The branchiae are absent. The chaetae include simple capillaries in the notopodia and compound spinigers in the neuropodia. The ventral cirrus, broadly triangular at the front and middle, becomes digitiform towards the rear. The type locality is the Mediterranean Sea. Its distribution includes the Northwestern and Northeastern Atlantic, Gulf of Mexico, Caribbean Sea, Mediterranean Sea, Red Sea, southern coasts of Africa, Indo-Pacific, Northwestern Pacific, as well as India Bay of Bangla, Arabian Sea, North Indian Ocean, and the Andaman and Nicobar Islands.
Generated_answer: Glycera tesselata is characterized by digitiform proboscidial papillae with only a straight, median, longitudinal ridge; ailerons with deeply incised bases; parapodia with short rounded postchaetal lobes; and a complete absence of branchiae. The prostomium has 12-14 rings, and the body is small (15–35 mm) with 70-100 segments. Presetal lobes of parapodia are triangular and equal, and postsetal lobes are shorter, rounded, and equal. Support: These features distinguish G. tesselata from similar species, especially in the structure of the proboscidial papillae and ailerons, and the absence of branchiae.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Glycera tridactyla?
Expected_answer: Glycera tridactyla Schmarda, 1861: The body rings are described as bi-annulated in the mid-body segments. The prostomium is conical with 11-14 rings. The proboscidal papillae consist of three types: 1) terminal fingernail-shaped papillae with short stalks and longitudinal ridges, 2) digitiform papillae with longitudinal ridges, and 3) oval-shaped papillae without ridges. The aileron has a pointed triangular base. The parapodia first appear uniramous, then become biramous. The prechaetal lobes are triangular with a broad base in the anterior and mid-body regions and become digitiform in posterior segments. The postchaetal lobes are short; notopodial lobes are triangular and longer than the rounded neuropodial lobes. The dorsal cirrus is conical to oval-shaped, located close to the parapodial base from the 3rd segment onward. Non-retractile digitiform branchiae are present between segments 17 and 22, positioned terminodorsally on the parapodia extending to the posterior end. The chaetae are simple capillaries in notopodia and compound spinigers in neuropodia. The ventral cirrus is broadly triangular in the anterior and mid-body, transforming into digitiform shape towards the posterior. The type locality is the Atlantic Ocean. Its geographic distribution includes the Mediterranean Sea, Black Sea, South Africa, Red Sea, Japan coast, South China Sea, New Guinea, Australia, Andaman Sea, and various locations around India such as the Arabian Sea, Bay of Bengal, and Andaman coast.
Generated_answer: Glycera tridactyla is characterized by proboscidial papillae with a terminal fingernail structure, short stalk, and longitudinal ridges; ailerons with pointed triangular bases; an elongated conical prostomium with 11–15 rings and four antennae; notopodial postchaetal lobes are triangular and longer than the rounded neuropodial lobes; non-retractile digitiform branchiae are present terminodorsally on parapodia from the anterior to the posterior end; mid-body segments are biannulate. Support: These features distinguish G. tridactyla from related species and are used for its identification.

Question: What are the taxonomic characteristics of Glycera unicornis?
Expected_answer: Glycera unicornis Lamarck, 1818, has body rings characterized by mid-body segments that are biannulate, with the anterior annulus roughly as long as or slightly longer than the posterior one. The prostomium is conical and bears 10-13 rings. Its proboscidal papillae consist of two types: numerous conical papillae with three U-shaped ridges, and isolated, broader oval to globular papillae without ridges. The aileron features a triangular base. Parapodia first appear uniramous for the initial two segments, then become biramous thereafter. The prechaetal lobe comprises two slender, triangular to digitiform lobes, while the postchaetal lobes are two in number, shorter, and rounded anteriorly; in subsequent segments, these lobes are elongated, slender, and roughly the same length. The dorsal cirrus, starting from the second parapodium, varies from conical to oval. Branchiae are retractile, with 1-2 digitiform branchial rami, and are positioned from about the 16th to the 30th parapodium near the posterior end. Chaetae include simple capillaries in the notopodia and compound spinigers in the neuropodia. The ventral cirrus is slender, triangular to digitiform, and approximately as long as the postchaetal lobes. The type locality is unknown. Its geographic distribution spans the Andaman Sea, Black Sea, North Sea, Mediterranean Sea, Madagascar, South China Sea, Java Sea, and regions in India such as Andhra Pradesh, Gujarat, Goa, Karnataka, Kerala, Maharashtra, Odisha, West Bengal, Tamil Nadu, and the Andaman coast.
Generated_answer: Glycera unicornis is characterized by a conical prostomium with 10–12 rings, proboscidial papillae mainly conical with 3 ridges, ailerons with triangular bases, mid-body parapodia with rounded or slightly blunt triangular postchaetal lobes (notopodial lobes usually broader and longer than neuropodial), and simple, retractile, digitiform branchiae situated medially on the anterior side of parapodia. It is the type species of the genus Glycera. Support: These features distinguish G. unicornis within Glyceridae and are used for its identification.
